newsitem.title: UK: UK pro-Europeans criticise Major's EU tactics.
newsitem.headline: UK pro-Europeans criticise Major's EU tactics.

text.p: Pro-European members of parliament criticised Prime Minister John Major for threatening wrecking tactics unless the European Union reverses a European Court of Justice ruling imposing a 48-hour working week on Britain.
Conservative MP Edwina Currie said Major was right to seek labour market flexibility but should make his case in a convincing and dignified manner.

"Thumping the table in Europe is childish, petulant and useless. It makes our partners turn away in disgust and they no longer listen to the serious points we make," Currie, vice-chairman of the European Movement, told a news conference.
Labour MP Giles Radice, the chairman of the group, said the wide exemptions to the 48-hour-week directive meant it was far fetched to talk of Britain being crippled by it.
"Rubbishing the ECJ is foolish because it is the Court which has enabled Britain to ensure that the single market is opened up to British exports," he said.
Earlier, Sir Jim Lester, a pro-European Conservative and a former employment minister, advised Major not to put Britain on a collision course with Europe over the directive.
"I think it's possibly wrong to try and make it into a big issue," he told Channel Four television.
Major threatened to block the Inter Governmental Conference on streamlining the EU's institutions as a prelude to welcoming new members unless Britain got its way on the 48-hour week.
Lester said he would not want to try to convince his constituents that it was not a good thing that they had three weeks paid holiday a year -- another of the provisions.

He also disputed Major's premise that the European Commission was wrong to have introduced the directive as a health and safety measure and not under the social chapter, from which Britain has an opt-out. "Nobody could argue that working long hours isn't a health and safety question," Lester said.
